Well, since I am being lazy I will just give you a brief story.
 
 I knew someone pretty close to me that had an abortion and her story was the reason why I became pro-choice. I remember having a discussion with my friend about this and he was pro-life. This was about 10yrs ago. Later on I realized that this lady was actually forced in a way to get an abortion because she felt no other choice (presure from family and community). I didn't really think about it much at the time and many years passed before I revisited the issue. In college I had a roommate that was pro-life and he would frequently do things to spread the word about being pro-life. He never said anything to me nor did he ask my opinion or force me to talk about the issue. However, I saw his passion for the subject and I figured I might want to revisit the issue because it someone is that concerned about something then it might be worth looking into. So I began asking questions such as "what about rape, incest" and the normal questions asked on these forums. I also read up a lot on pro-choice and pro-life websites. A main things I saw was how pro-life people conducted themselves as opposed to how pro-choice people conducted themselves (in general). Pro-life people TENDED to be fairly kind, less selfish, and other traits common with religious people (but they were not all religious). Pro-chioce people seemed to nice however they were more concerned about themselves as opposed to others. They seemed to place a value on the "I" as opposed to the "you". This was just an observation I made and by no means reflects everyone. So after conducting much research and talking to my roommate often I realized that a value on human life has to be a top priority for anything to really work in our world. This alone has led to everything else falling into place. When one can structure what they believe and realize the value system they have then they will be consistent and a better overall person. I have noticed a change in myself actually. I have noticed that guy on the side of the road that is poor, I actually stop for the people on the side of the road with a flat tire, I don't see people as worse or better then me and I see what is meant by "we are all equal". So basically after I saw that the unborn is a person I realized it is equal to me and deserves to live as I do. People talk about rape and incest and things like that and all of these things are terrible but none are worth killing an innocent life. I don't see any gain in destroying two lives because of the greed of another. I feel as if I am a lucky person to have met the person that gave me insite into abortion and many other issues. I have my thoughts about how all of this happened but that is for another time, I will just say that we all need to open our ears because their is Someone talking.

Winston: "by definition [altruism] cannot exist" means that the concept as defined is incoherent in practice.
 
 In the casual sense provided by dictionary.com, altruism (n.) is: "Unselfish concern for the welfare of others; selflessness." And we can reasonably construe it such that it refers to concern for the welfare of others without profiting from that concern. 
 
 But then we think about how we might express a concern for the welfare of others without somehow profiting from that concern, it seems that even the most apparently selfless act of altruism profits us somehow - typically through some sense of moral satisfaction or spiritual uplift or satisfaction of conscience. Whether an act is really an act of 'altruism', as ordinarily defined, is an open question whose answer is contingent upon what is considered profitable. 
 
 Take Mother Teresa for example, and her altruistic action in Calcutta. It could be said that her actions were not truly altruistic because they satisfied a desire of hers: to help the needy. 
 
 Denying the existence of altruism then is simply denying the existence whatever the term 'altruism' refers to when it is defined as: "Unselfish concern for the welfare of others; selflessness." or something similar.

 "If it's something that you feel is important in pursuing, I'd recommend a brief round of conceptual analysis to establish an effective definition of altruism such that we can attribute it to people without running into the problem that Bell noted." 
 
 I meant that if you're really interested in establishing an effective definition of altruism, then you should post some conceptual analysis of the term. But since you obviously want me to do it, I'll see what I can do. 
 
 Step One, Primitives
 This step defines the meaning and structure of the definition. 
 
 For primitive symbols, we'll take all of the words in the english language, plus grammar markers, and so on to be our set of constants, variables, predicates, and operators. Dictionary.com and Thesaurus.com will stand in as our lists of these primitive terms. 
 
 Certain syntactic conventions will apply such that:
 'either...or' will denote exclusive disjunction
 'both...and' will denote conjunction 
 'and/or' will denote inclusive disjunction
 'if...then' will denote the conditional
 'not' will denote negation
 'if and only if' will denote the biconditional
 'all', 'some', 'none' will denote quantifiers
 and so on. 
 
 Step Two, Examples
 This step gives us paradigmatic examples of the concept to which the term in question is attached.
 
 1. Mother Teresa's actions in Calcutta.
 
 2. Giving money to charity.
 
 3. Feeding others before yourself.
 
 There probably better ones out there, and please feel free to suggest some. 
 
 Step Three, Initial Definition
 This set is to provide a ballpark string of primitive terms from which the analysis may begin. 
 
 Altruism (n.): "Unselfish concern for the welfare of others; selflessness."
 
 Step Four, Substitutions
 This set is where the work is done. Primitive terms are substituted for synonymous terms, according to the arrangement of our lists of primitive terms. A word is substituted with another, and the meaning of the aggregate (though not the primitive parts) is considered in relation to the examples given as paradigmatic.
 
 1a. The first primitive symbol is 'unselfish', synonyms are "altruistic, benevolent, charitable, chivalrous, denying, devoted, disinterested, extroverted, generous, giving, helpful, humanitarian, incorruptible, indulgent, liberal, loving, magnanimous, noble, open-handed, self-effacing, self-forgetting, self-sacrificing, selfless"
 
 1b. The various permutations: 
 i. Benevolent concern for the welfare of others; selflessness.

 Duplication is where a synonymous term is synonymous with a different term, a problem of amphiboly.
 
 Inconsistent is where a synonymous term is antonymous with a different term, a problem of the excluded middle.
 
 Confused is where the sense of a synonymous term is different from the original term. 
 
 None is where both the sense and the reference of a term is apparently preserved through substitution.
 
 Of xxii synonyms, only [v, vii-xi] appear to preserve the meaning of the string. These terms will be held over to Step Five. 
 
 2a. The first primitive symbol is 'concern', synonyms are: "affair, burden, care, charge, company, corporation, deportment, enterprise, establishment, field, firm, house, interest, involvement, job, jungle, matter, mission, multinational, occupation, organization, outfit, responsibility, shooting match, task, thing, transaction, worry."
 
 2b. As 1b, except substituting synonyms for the second term in the string. 
 
 2c. As 1c.
 
 Etc, as many sets of sub-steps as terms in initial definition (5 in this case).
 
 Step Five, Construction of Definition 
 Using the sets of synonymous terms derived by Step 4, all combinations of these synonyms are constructed and those that fit the paradigmatic examples comprise the effective definition of 'altruism'.

Bell: 
 
 It seems that altruism is best regarded as the attitude by which an act is performed, with no implicit or explicit motivation based on a possible or actual return on investment. Sure, you could get a return on an altruistic act, but the act itself is performed with no intention of gaining reward. 
 
 However it also seems more reasonable to say that acts are more or less altruistic depending on the degree of implicit motivation behind the act. 
 
 Helping someone that you hate and do not want to help seems to be the only purely altruistic situation.

Altruism=unselfish concern for others.
 
 Strictly speaking, I think that anything a human chooses to do is done in that human's self-interest. If I have concern for others, it is because I have been in that place and I hope that if I were in that place again others would have concern for me. If, on occasion, I can leap the bounds of my experience and have concern for others who are in situations that I have never suffered it is because I would never like to be in the same situation and, again, I would hope that others would, likewise, be concerned about my situation should it be my fate to suffer such a state.
 
 I see absolutely nothing at all wrong with self-interest if it does not oppress the self-interests of others unless those others are oppressing the self-interests of others.
 
 And, furthermore, I think I might start a School of New Philosophy based on the righteousness of self-interest.

Steeeeve:
 
 No, argument by definition is always absurd because definitions are not the things that they describe. To say that a person is a living human being because 'persons' are defined as 'living human beings' is question begging, and thus absurd in the logical sense, because doing so begs the question of whether a person is accurately described by the definition 'living human beings'. 
 
 Simply put there is no reasonable way of arguing a logical absurdity. 
 
 Arguing the difference between 'human' and 'person', however, is thus quite reasonable if that argument depends on differences between whatsoever those terms actually refer to, rather than differences in how their definitions are constructed. Instead of arguing definitions we are arguing about what those definitions ostensibly refer to, and that is much more reasonable than confusing definitions with the objects they refer to. 
 
 That is also why it is useful to define terms through conceptual analysis prior to making arguments so that terms are understood to represent the subject of the argument and not be the subject of argument themselves. Incidentally this confusion of thing and representation is precisely the gaping flaw in Anselm's ontological argument for the existence of God... 
 
 But back to whether human foeti are persons. Since the 'human' refers to biological entities and the term 'person' refers to legal and moral entities, obviously any definition that equates the two merely reflects a contingent political identity rather than a necessary metaphysical identity.

Steeeeve: 
 
 Let me try again. There are three different things at work here: 
 
 i. Terms,
 ii. Definitions of terms,
 iii. Referents of terms. 
 
 The terms, propositions or statements, of an argument are like labels in that they denote some semantic object.
 
 Definitions are representations of what a term denotes. 
 
 Referents of terms are the things which terms label and definitions describe.
 
 Trying to make arguments about the objects that terms label by resorting to the definitions of those terms, such as making an arguement by definition, is absurd because definitions beg the question with regard to the meaning of semantic objects. 
 
 It is equivalent to trying to pass a picture of a thing off as the thing itself, absurd. 
 
 Now, what we want to do is talk about those objects being represented, rather than the way in which they are represented. 
 
 Objects are subject specific things. Numbers, for example, are objects in mathematics. Spatio-temporal objects are objects in empirical science. Humans are objects of the subject of biology. Persons are objects in both the arts of ethics and law. We refer to the subjects of those objects to give us paradigm examples of those objects. 
 
 Conceptual analysis with reference to subject specific paradigm examples will give us a collection of terms to let us identify the object about which we will speak. In biology we talk about human, masses of flesh and bone and whatnot, distinguished by a set of empirical properties. In law and ethics we talk about persons, things distinguished by a set of legal or ethical properties.
 
 Obviously humans are physical things that we use the term 'human' to denote and use biological terms to define. Likewise persons are social things that we use the term 'person' to denote and use legal terms to define.
 
 Humans are not persons because humans are different things than persons. Much like colours and rocks are different things, or Bill Gates and the richest man in America are different things. 
 
 Which should answer your question about the difference in these terms, namely that they refer to different things, not merely a difference in token but also a token in type. You're familiar with the type/token distinction I hope. 
 
 Moving on to answer your first reductio example: a feline is a cat because 'feline' and 'cat' both denote the same object, a type of animal.
 
 Likewise your second reductio example of 'person' being redefined to exclude blacks is correct in the sense that the set of objects denoted by the term 'person' has been can be changed as the institution of personhood for corporations demonstrates. However, it is incorrect in supposing that this is because the definition of the term as changed. A definition, as I keep noting, is merely a description and as such is vulnerable to error as well as not being what the term actually denotes.

 Symbiote is correct, and since we're working from the same set of principles I don't see anything worth debating with him. 
 
 But back to why arguments turning on personhood are straw-man arguments. 
 
 You have made the assertion that because foeti are human, they are persons and we cannot kill persons. 
 
 I've pointed out that the terms 'human' and 'person' cannot mean the same thing through reference to their definitions due to circularity of definition. 
 
 Likewise we cannot simply assume identity through colloquial use as that begs the question of what it is that makes them the same. 
 
 I've also pointed out that they denote different things vis-a-vis biological and legal entities. 
 
 There are persons that are not human, such as corporations, and there are humans that are not persons, such as dead people. 
 
 Since there may be humans that are non-persons, the category of person is not entailed solely by the category of human. 
 
 Obviously a person may be a human or may not be a human, that is basic modal logic. Likewise a human may be a person or may not be a person. Such identities are contingent. 
 
 Where such identities are contingent, there is no necessary connection between humans and persons.
 
 Since the abortion debate is about a conflict between persons, trying to prove that abortion is wrong because foeti have personhood by dint of being human is not merely a bad argument but also a straw-man with regard to the issue as whether a foetus is a person is beside the point as there are cases where the killing of innocent persons is permissable

Steeeeve:
 
 I was referring to persons in the moral sense, but I believe it also holds for the legal sense that includes corporations. In casual conversation we might might use the terms 'human' and 'person' interchangeably. In such situations we can be sloppy with our terms. 
 
 In ethics, law, and biology, the subjects at hand we require somewhat more technical rigour in the use of our terms. Lawyers, legislators, and judges determine what legal objects are denoted by the term 'person'. Doctors, physicists, and biologists and everyone else involved in the empirical sciences determine what physical objects are denoted by the term 'human'. 
 
 The plasticity in what the term person denotes of one of the reasons that humans are not necessarily persons, unless by political or social fiat. The term 'person' for example did not magically change in the USA in 1937 unless you regard politics as some sort of magic.
 
 Back to respecting persons. Notice that I have invoked the principle of ceteris paribus, "all else being equal". Saying that a fetus is a person, all else being equal, merely gives it equality to other persons where only personhood is considered. 
 
 Seeing as the decision of whether or not to kill a person depends on other facts not being equal, and independent of a respect for personhood, it's a fallacy to assert that the sole quality of personhood somehow determines whether or not to kill a person. 
 
 The fact that many people feel that killing should turn solely on possession of the property of personhood merely means that those people have false or misleading intuitions about when persons should be killed. 
 
 So as you may have gathered by now my respect for persons has likewise nothing to do with whether they should be killed or not.

As a student of ethics, I feel quite confident to say that the results of Nazi experimentation on Jewish concentration camp was wrong and that the Nazi opinion that such lives spent were worth it is wrong. Much like I feel confident that the lives of the Allied soldiers who liberated such camps were well spent. 
 
 In claiming these things without providing an explanation for how they are so, I am begging the question, so let me provide one according to a stricly consequentialist account according to expected value comparisons: 
 
 1. Take the number of Jewish lives lost to Nazi medical experimentation. Let's say 6,000,000 as an effective estimate for the period between 1938-1946. Adjust the cost of that loss of life to account for the degradation that those Jews suffered through those experiments and the circumstances surrounding them using a multiplier, say 100x. Multiply this number further by the likelihood of those Jews suffering and dying at the hands of the Nazis, 100% or 1.0 
 
 2. Take the number of lives saved as a result of Nazi medical experimentation. Let's say 1,000,000 of the following two centuries. Adjust that benefit to account for the number of lives that have been improved as a result of Nazi medical experimentation, say 100x. Multiply this number further by the likelihood of those lives having been saved or improved as a result of said Nazi medical experimentation, 100% or 1.0 
 
 3. Place the costs and benefits together as a ratio which will leave you with a rough estimate of the worth of those Nazi medical experiments. I'd suggest that accurate numbers for these costs and benefits would yield a negative ratio, but for the sake of not making a forgone conclusion let's suppose instead that things turned out such that those Nazi medical experiments on Jews had an overall positive impact. 
 
 Repeat with stem-cell research:
 1. Take the number of lives that may be lost stem-cell research, say 6,000,000 over the next few years. Adjust that cost of that loss of life by the degradation in those embryos' quality of life, 20x. Multiply this number by the likelihood of such embryos being harmed, 100%, or 1.0. 
 
 2. Take the number of lives that may be saved as a result of stem-cell experimentation. Let's say 50,000,000 over the next few years. Adjust that benefit to account for the number of lives that have been improved as a result of stem-cell experimentation, say 10x. Multiply this number by the likelihood of such people existing in the next two centuries, 50% or 0.5.
 
 3. Place the costs and benefits together as a ratio which will leave you with a rough estimate of the worth of stem-cell research. I'd suggest that accurate numbers for these costs and benefits would yield a positive ratio.
 
 Now, let us compare the two ratios keeping in mind that the margin of error in our estimated values has been controlled for by the likelihood of these values being real (people existing, embryos being harmed, etc). 
 
 Nazi Experiments: 600,000,000:100,000,000, or 6:1
 Stem Cell Research: 120,000,000:250,000,000, or 12:25
 
 Even if the Nazi research saved lives, it saved them at an outrageous and immoral cost of killing or torturing 6 to save or improve 1 is morally monstrous. If stem-cell research saves lives, it saves them at a morally profitable balance of more than 2 saved or improved for 1 killed. We can't really even say that embryos are tortured, as they are harvested before any form of nervous system is developed. 
 
 With regard to Nazi intentions, I have difficulty seeing how pursuing stem-cell research to benefit all of humanity is comparable to trying to prove the racial superiority of Germans, or figure out how protect Nazi soldiers against chemical weapons and adverse environmental conditions. The Nazi reasoning behind the detention and abuse of Jews was xenophobic, nationalist, and contaminated with more than a little common cruelty. Until stem-cell researchers start claiming that lesser races are ideal expendible subjects for stem-cell research, that such research is for the glory of the [insert ideologically defined race here] people, or that stem-cell research is kind of fun because you can see the little blastocysts wiggle in pain, then you're making a fallacious comparison between the two when you say they share a similar thought process. 
 
 The reason why Godwin's law works, I'd say, is because people are used to tossing around the epiphet of "Nazi" or "Facist" without really understanding the motivations and politics of those groups such that they are an internet boogy-man used to demonize other people or groups of people.

 Fortunately the United Nations did not invent human rights, and certainly not the legal and civil rights that you enjoy as a USA citizen. I certainly agree with you that rights are not determined by social norms, as rights are conceptually prior to what a social norm may be. 
 
 However, unlike your belief about rights being granted by some supernatural power I hold that rights exist conceptually like numbers do, as things that we discover empirically when we elucidate systems of concepts. Regardless of how the framers of your consitution understood the a priori nature of rights, the concepts exist and operate separate from that understanding much like real-world objects do not require an observer for their reality. 
 
 Now, an argument about the moral or legal permissability of abortion, I argue, can only be effectively decided by reference to the concept of rights, and any systems of rights that may be entailed by such a concept. 
 
 The problem of philosophy being used to prove a conclusion is a typical Thomist failing, and you'll find that analytic philosophy is about biting the bullet with whatever answer you manage to compute.
